section.title: Configuring the Monitoring Email Notification Settings
section.para: The monitoring service, based on Monasca, allows you to configure an external SMTP server for email notifications when alarms trigger. In &kw-hos;, you have the option to specify a SMTP server for email notifications. These steps will assist in this process.

If you are going to use the email notifiication feature of the monitoring service, you must set the configuration options with valid email settings including an SMTP server and valid email addresses. The email server is not provided by &kw-hos;, but must be specified in the configuration file described below. The email server must support SMTP.

section.title: Configuring monitoring notification settings during initial installation

listitem.para: Log in to the &lcm;.
To change the SMTP server configuration settings edit the following file:
Enter your email server settings. Here is an example snippet showing the configuration file contents, uncomment these lines before entering your environment details.
listitem.screen: smtp-settings: # server: mailserver.examplecloud.com # port: 25 # timeout: 15 # These are only needed if your server requires authentication # user: # password:
listitem.para: This table explains each of these values:

entry.para: The server entry must be uncommented and set to a valid hostname or IP Address.
If your SMTP server is running on a port other than the standard 25, then uncomment the port line and set it your port.
If your email server is heavily loaded, the timeout parameter can be uncommented and set to a larger value. 15 seconds is the default.
If your SMTP server requires authentication, then you can configure user and password. Use double quotes around the password to avoid issues with special characters.

section.title: Monasca and Apache Commons validator
section.para: The Monasca notification uses a standard Apache Commons validator to validate the configured &kw-hos; domain names before sending the notification over webhook. Monasca notification supports some non-standard domain names, but not all. See the Domain Validator documentation for more information:
You should ensure that any domains that you use are supported by IETF and IANA. As an example, .local is not listed by IANA and is invalid but .gov and .edu are valid.

listitem.para: Connect to and log in to the &opscon;. See for assistance.
On the Home screen, click the menu represented by 3 horizontal lines (&opscon-hamburger-icon;).
From the menu that slides in on the left side, click Home, and then Alarm Explorer.
On the Alarm Explorer page, at the top, click the Notification Methods text.
On the Notification Methods page, find the row with the Default Email notification.
In the Default Email row, click the details icon (&opscon-detail-icon;), then click Edit.
On the Edit Notification Method: Default Email page, in Name, Type, and Address/Key, type in the values you want to use.
On the Edit Notification Method: Default Email page, click Update Notification.

important.para: Once the notification has been added, using the procedures using the Ansible playbooks will not change it.
